paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Does intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: 78 tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments receiving combination therapy.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: 84 tumor-bearing mice pooled across matched controls (vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle).

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Retrospective cohort of 130 metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: 43 patients in the human cohort who received prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: 87 patients in the human cohort who did not receive prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.
